review: It was absolutely terrible. So many inconsistencies and angry upset customers. Very very unorganized and poorly managed company. There was no communication with the company itself and the business who partake in the coupon systems.

poor communication, lay-offs are rampent, managers are terrible, upper management does whatever they want no matter who/what it effects, no clue how to run a business

a lot of immature manager and still trying to figure out the opportunity and what it all Intel. Not a lot of clear direction or incentive to thrive with the company. Pay plans was changed three time in my tenure with the company.

When I joined Groupon I had a thought of what it would be, based on coming from a technology company like itelligence.  Groupon surprised me in many areas. Constant changes in performance metrics, clueless "managers," little  tier 2 support. It's like someone went to a dorm and hired everyone there for their first big boy job. Over staffed and poorly managed. When they are busy you get your hours in. When they slow down they want to often send you home. Lucky to get 32 hours in .
Leadership for GSO  supporting  team is a revolving door.  Latest Management is unprofessional, bias and untrustworthy.  Very political

typical day: 2-4 meetings with business partners, cold calling, emailing and preparing proposals. hunting for new leads and accounts. reviewing deals previews and corrections mistakes and changes. Handling after sales payments. Creating new deal themes and ideas.

Groupon is a company that moves very fast. Changes are a constant in the sales organization. That change can be motivating to some, however over the last year those changes have been short sighted. Lot's of the changes made have not taken into account the businesses we work with or how certain changes will make the sales side of Groupon more difficult. From a sales rep's eyes Groupon is changing so businesses have less control over their campaign on Groupon's platform and Groupon is asking for more money from the businesses to run these campaigns. These two factors impact sales reps directly and ultimately lower Groupon's ability to bring new and exciting businesses to their subscribers.

Management has NO CLUE what they are doing. No vision. No idea. No one knows what one department is doing. Our entire department got laid off one day with no warning. Then I found out this is Groupon's M.O. and they do this all the time. BE WARNED!

Would advise against working working here for a long period of time.  On the positive the culture can be fun and opportunities to move around.  On the downside it can be very hard to get promoted and hard to believe in direction the company is going

Writing this from my desk, I really wish I never came here. Groupon's environment is fantastic. You work with great people. The work life balance is great. They're flexible. It's relaxed. However, it's the only thing that keeps you there - people & comfortability. They now require that you make 35 calls a day which is nothing, but it's how they compare you. They quota you based on points which have 0 compatibility to the amount of profit you make for the company or how good the business is. It's a completely unknown number. They change their goals, mission, outlook, and commission every 2-3 quarters based upon Wall Street. It's senior leadership, specifically on the sales side, is incredibly poor and short sighted. Very good people, but they have no idea how to run a sales force. They reward behavior that shouldn't be rewarded. Most importantly maybe, they have zero clue on long-term outlook. For example, if an employee leaves there is no procedure on accounts, etc. They make decisions without knowing how to manage the rippling effects. Very, very poorly run. If you're a kid out of college go for it. However, they don't know how to develop sales talent/skills, nor retain it.
